body_html:
So it seems like you're having an issue with bazel being able to download dependencies. Unfortunately, debugging that isn't something that we have the bandwidth for in the TensorFlow team. I'd encourage you to seek advice on stackoverflow and/or bazel.

That said, one possibility is that there is some configuration issue preventing Java programs from fetching data over the network (bazel is written in Java). Is there a simpler program (such as something like https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/networking/urls/readingURL.html) you can use to validate network access from the JVM?

An alternative workaround: we did see someone try this trick: #5029 (comment)
to work with pre-downloaded packages.

Hope that helps!

That said, one possibility is that there is some configuration issue preventing Java programs from fetching data over the network (bazel is written in Java). Is there a simpler program (such as something like https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/networking/urls/readingURL.html) you can use to validate network access from the JVM?

body:
So it seems like you're having an issue with bazel being able to download dependencies. Unfortunately, debugging that isn't something that we have the bandwidth for in the TensorFlow team. I'd encourage you to seek advice on stackoverflow and/or bazel. 

That said, one possibility is that there is some configuration issue preventing Java programs from fetching data over the network (bazel is written in Java). Is there a simpler program (such as something like https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/networking/urls/readingURL.html) you can use to validate network access from the JVM?

An alternative workaround: we did see someone try this trick: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/5029#issuecomment-254769127
to work with pre-downloaded packages.

Hope that helps!
